head.supplied: 22 August 1893 ¶ ¶ I am very glad that the matter of the supplementary volume is amicably settled. It is best that the Baron should do it, that is if he will. ¶ ¶ But as I told him frankly he could ...

div.p: Box, 2, item 3898, C. T. While papers, Queensland Herbarium Archives.

To proof.
copy sent by Lionel Gilbert, November 1997.
22 August 1893
It is not clear from Gilbert's transcription if this is part of the letter or an editorial addition.
I am very glad that the matter of the supplementary volume is amicably settled. It is best that the Baron should do it, that is if he will.

But as I told him frankly he could not expect to occupy the ground and do nothing. You have had at any rate the satisfaction of bringing him to the point. He has also promised to do it on the lines of Bentham's work. I entirely agree with you as to all you say of the merits of that great botanist's work.

No one, I suppose, ever did botanical work so incomparably well, though I think Sir Joseph Hooker has more instinctive genius for penetrating affinities. I think in retiring in favour of the Baron you have behaved gracefully and with judgment. I am sure in the retrospect you will feel that you have done the right and handsome thing. The Flora of Queensland must afford you still an immense field much of which has still to be worked.
